properties.description: Not Applicable (no global hypothesis specified for this run)
Quote from Capt. Levi Preston of Danvers, Massachusetts, stating Americans rebelled because 'we always had governed ourselves, and we always meant to. They didn’t mean we should.'
British policy of salutary neglect over 150 years
Colonists became accustomed to running their own affairs
End of the French and Indian War in 1763
British policy significantly changed after the French and Indian War
Thirteen Colonies sought greater autonomy from Britain
British national debt increased significantly after the French and Indian War (£133 million)
Cost of permanently stationing 10,000 soldiers in North America (£360,000 a year)
British Parliament imposed new taxes on the colonies
Control of the colonies' western lands turned over to British officials in Montreal
Mechanism by which British government responded to post-war financial situation and territorial expansion, leading to colonial discontent.
Parliament passed the Sugar Act, decreasing duties but increasing enforcement
Grenville proposed direct taxes on the colonies
Parliament passed the Stamp Act, imposing direct taxes for the first time
Colonists lacked direct representation in the British Parliament
Taxation without representation violates the rights of Englishmen.
Mechanism describing how colonists organized and executed resistance against British tax policies.
Sons of Liberty used public demonstrations, boycotts, and threats of violence
British tax laws became unenforceable
Delegates from nine colonies convened the Stamp Act Congress in New York City
Stamp Act Congress issued a 'Declaration of Rights and Grievances'
The Declaration of Rights and Grievances stated that colonists were equal to other British citizens and taxes without representation violated their rights as Englishmen.
Stamp Act Congress organized a boycott on imports of all British merchandise
British taxes after the French and Indian War were primarily imposed to compensate for wartime costs and the cost of stationing troops.
Benjamin Franklin's testimony to Parliament arguing that colonies spent heavily in the war, further taxes were unjust, and might cause rebellion.
Parliament repealed the Stamp Act
Widespread celebrations in the colonies following the repeal of the Stamp Act
Parliament passed the Declaratory Act asserting full power to make laws for colonies 'in all cases whatsoever'
British Parliament passed the Townshend Acts, placing duties on goods and establishing a Customs Board in Boston
John Dickinson's pamphlet 'Letters from a Farmer in Pennsylvania' arguing against the constitutionality of Townshend Acts as their purpose was revenue, not trade regulation.
Colonists responded to Townshend Acts by organizing new boycotts of British goods
Assembly of Massachusetts Bay Colony issued a circular letter urging colonies to coordinate resistance
Governor dissolved the Massachusetts Assembly after it refused to rescind the circular letter
A riot broke out in Boston over the seizure of John Hancock's sloop Liberty for alleged smuggling
Customs officials were forced to flee Boston after the Sloop Liberty riot
British deployed troops to Boston in response to unrest
Parliament reactivated the Treason Act 1543, calling for trials in England for subjects outside the realm
Threat of trials under the Treason Act caused widespread outrage in the colonies
British soldiers fired into a crowd, killing five people
Description of the Boston Massacre: crowd gathered, threw objects, soldier fell, soldiers panicked and fired, hitting 11, killing 5.
Widespread descriptions of the Boston Massacre turned colonial sentiment against the British
Parliament repealed most Townshend duties, except the tax on tea
The crisis temporarily resolved after the repeal of most Townshend duties
American patriots burned the British warship HMS Gaspee enforcing trade regulations
Private letters published from Gov. Hutchinson claiming colonists couldn't enjoy all English liberties and Lt. Gov. Oliver calling for direct payment of officials.
Contents of Hutchinson/Oliver letters used as evidence of a systematic plot against American rights
Governor Hutchinson discredited in the eyes of the people
Colonial Assembly petitioned for Governor Hutchinson's recall
Mechanism describing how patriots built networks for communication and coordination across colonies.
Samuel Adams set about creating new Committees of Correspondence
Committees of Correspondence linked Patriots in all 13 colonies
Committees of Correspondence eventually provided the framework for a rebel government

properties.name: Thomas Jefferson
properties.role: Virginia Patriot leader, Primary author Declaration of Independence

properties.description: Virginia set up its Committee of Correspondence
The Committees of Correspondence became the leaders of American resistance and largely determined the war effort at the state and local level.
Committees took charge of enforcing boycott, examining merchant records, publishing names of those defying.
Parliament passed the Tea Act lowering price of taxed tea to help British East India Company
Tea Act opposed by those resisting taxes and smugglers who would lose business
In most colonies, consignees were forced to resign and tea was turned back
Massachusetts Governor Hutchinson refused to allow Boston merchants to give in to pressure and turn back tea
A town meeting in Boston determined that the tea would not be landed
Group led by Samuel Adams, dressed as Indigenous people, boarded ships and dumped tea into Boston Harbor (£10,000 worth)
The Boston Tea Party was a seminal event in the American Revolution's escalation.
Description of the Boston Tea Party event: men dressed as Indigenous people boarding ships and dumping tea.
British government responded by passing four laws known as the Intolerable Acts
Passage of the Intolerable Acts (Massachusetts Government Act, Administration of Justice Act, Boston Port Act, Quartering Act 1774)
The Intolerable Acts, while intended to punish Massachusetts, expanded and intensified the revolutionary cause.
The Intolerable Acts effectively ended self-government in Massachusetts.
The Intolerable Acts served to expand and intensify the revolutionary cause.
Massachusetts patriots issued the Suffolk Resolves
Massachusetts patriots formed an alternative shadow government known as the Provincial Congress
Provincial Congress began training militia outside British-occupied Boston
First Continental Congress convened with representatives from 12 colonies
Province of Georgia joined the Congress
Congress began coordinating Patriot resistance through underground networks of committees
Congress called for a boycott of all British goods beginning December 1, 1774
Existence of colonial militias in every colony
Colonial militias had military experience from the French and Indian War
Patriots became armed and unified against Parliament
Battles of Lexington and Concord launched the American Revolutionary War
The American Revolutionary War began
Second Continental Congress convened
Second Continental Congress formed the Continental Army
George Washington appointed commander-in-chief of the Continental Army
Washington and the Continental Army responded by surrounding Boston
British forced to withdraw from Boston by sea
Patriots in control in every colony
King George III proclaimed Massachusetts to be in a state of open defiance and rebellion
Second Continental Congress began debating and deliberating on the Articles of Confederation
Congress passed the Lee Resolution, affirming support for national independence
Second Continental Congress unanimously adopted the Declaration of Independence
France entered the American Revolutionary War, supporting the colonial cause
Siege of Yorktown, a decisive military victory for the Continental Army and allies
Roughly 7,500 British troops led by Charles Cornwallis were captured during the Siege of Yorktown
The decisive victory at the Siege of Yorktown led King George III and the British to negotiate an end to colonial rule and acknowledge independence.
Account of the Siege of Yorktown resulting in the capture of British troops and leading to British negotiation.
Collapse of King George III's control of Parliament
Consensus in Parliament that the war should be ended on American terms
King George III and the British negotiated an end to colonial rule in the colonies
British acknowledged the independence of the United States
British signed the Treaty of Paris, codifying independence and granting territory
Establishment of the sovereign United States of America
End of the First British Empire
Began the Age of Revolution
World's first federal republic founded on the consent of the governed and the rule of law
First permanently successful overthrow of monarchical colonial rule
Dissolution of British America, formation of British North America and Spanish Florida

properties.name: Loyalists
properties.role: Colonists remaining loyal to the British Crown

properties.description: About 60,000 Loyalists migrated to other British territories
British Parliament viewed itself as the supreme lawmaking authority throughout the Empire
British Parliament argued colonists had 'virtual representation'

properties.source_text_quote: its 'Declaration of Rights and Grievances' argued that taxation without representation violated their rights as Englishmen
explaining that the colonies had spent heavily in manpower, money, and blood defending the empire, and that further taxes to pay for those wars were unjust
argued against the constitutionality of the acts because their purpose was to raise revenue and not to regulate trade
On March 5, 1770, a large crowd gathered around a group of British soldiers...soldiers panicked and fired into the crowd. They hit 11 people; three civilians died...and two died shortly after.

The committees became the leaders of the American resistance...When the First Continental Congress decided to boycott British products, the colonial and local Committees took charge, examining merchant records and publishing the names of merchants who attempted to defy the boycott
a group of men, led by Samuel Adams and dressed to evoke the appearance of Indigenous people, boarded the ships...and dumped £10,000 worth of tea...into Boston Harbor.
which effectively ended self-government in Massachusetts
but also served to expand and intensify the revolutionary cause

a decisive victory by Washington and the Continental Army in the Siege of Yorktown inspired King George III and the British to negotiate an end to colonial rule in the colonies and acknowledge their independence
'…we always had governed ourselves, and we always meant to. They didn’t mean we should.'
